newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat closes lower on charts, soy spillover.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat closes lower on charts, soy spillover.

text.p: CBOT wheat futures closed lower, weakened by chart based selling and spillover weakness from the soybean pit, traders said.
Concern about the outlook for spring wheat plantings and talk that dry weather in southwest Kansas may be emerging as a problem for the hard red winter wheat crop limited losses.

"We are seeing more snowfall up there (in the spring wheat belt) today and it is going to be almost impossible to avoid flooding and some planting delays," Goldenberg-Hehmeyer analyst Bob Lekberg said.
Dealers said wheat charts turned bearish late last week when the May contract sunk rapidly after earlier rising to its highest level in more than a year.
"We did a lot of damage to the charts Friday," one dealer commented.
They cited news that Egypt had bought 150,000 tonnes of wheat. The total comprised 100,000 tonnes from Australia and 50,000 tonnes from either Australia or the U.S.
May wheat closed 3-1/2 cents a bushel lower at $3.86-1/2. Other months were off two cents to up one cent.
Volume on wheat was estimated at 14,000 lots.
